properties.name: 11/06/07 - Flasher shocked woman posting letter
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WOMAN had a shock when she tried to post an item at a house in Buckley only to feel the occupant\'s manhood through the letterbox. Darren Wilcock, 36, of Powell Road in Buckley, admitted exposing himself by placing his genitals into the letter box of his front door just as the woman was making the delivery. But Wilcock claimed his actions were not directed at the woman and said a friend had previously played such a prank on him. He believed it was his friend who was approaching his home, and decided to do the same to him. Magistrates were told he had not realised there was a woman on the other side of the door. However, while on bail for that offence, Wilcock admitted committing a further offence when he pulled up his jacket and exposed his genitals to two women who were passing in a car. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943140

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Inquiry calls for cockle fishermen to be restricted to 50 per year
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCOCKLE fishing on the Dee Estuary is likely to be restricted to 50 fishermen per year. A four-day public inquiry held in Chester last week looking into the problem of falling cockle stocks in the estuary heard from local cockle fishermen, environmentalists and representatives from the Environment Agency Wales (EAW). Alan Winstone, environment manager at EAW, said: "The inquiry was very constructive and very useful. Everyone had the opportunity to put forward their views and we had a good representation from the fishermen and I think everyone\'s found it a very beneficial process." He said the inquiry found a Regulatory Order was needed to develop a viable and sustainable fishery and to avoid the boom and bust situation that exists at the moment, which has seen cockle stocks fall. Mr Winstone said the inquiry looked at the number of licences that should be granted and there was general agreement that 50 was the right number. A proposed licence fee of £992 was reasonable because it enabled the Agency to recover the costs of managing the fishery. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943265

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Man's rape conviction quashed after six years in jail
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN who has spent more than six years in prison after being convicted of raping and assaulting a teenage girl will have his convictions overturned by three top judges this week. Kenneth Samuels, 50, of Maes Glyndwr, Treuddyn, was sentenced to 10 years in jail at Mold Crown Court in January 2001 after a jury found him guilty of the rape and indecent assault of the girl. But Mr Samuels always protested his innocence and on Friday – after the case had been referred to the Criminal Appeal Court by the Criminal Cases Review Commission (CCRC), the body set up to investigate possible miscarriages of justice – three judges said the convictions were "unsafe". Representing Mr Samuels, Peter Wilcock told the court new evidence had come to light since the convictions, which, if it had been available at the time of the trial, could have influenced the way in which the jury viewed the case. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943819

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Neighbour rescues woman in flat blaze
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN helped rescue one of his neighbours who was choking on thick smoke after a fire broke out in her flat. Residents at a block of flats at Fairy Road, Wrexham, escaped on Friday night after hearing a smoke alarm, and have praised the swift response of fire crews. David Davies, 33, helped a 44-year-old woman out of the building after seeing her struggling in the smoke in one of the flats upstairs. His girlfriend Jane Prince, 36, helped get the children including her daughter, Cathy, four, and other residents out of the building. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943405

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Probe after arsonists strike at city flat
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE are on the hunt for arsonists who attacked a flat in Chester. The fire, which caused extensive damage to 43 Medlar Close, Lache, was put out by firefighters at 3.30 on Sunday morning. Flat owner Kathy May, who at the time was away in Cumbria with her six-year-old son, was being comforted by family yesterday. Her sister, Stephanie Whyborn, told the Leader: "I feel so sorry for her. "Everything has gone, her clothes, her son\'s clothes, her bed was burnt – everything." The fire, on the second floor, caused extensive smoke damage to four other flats within the building. Two pumps from Chester Fire Station attended the incident. Two women from the flat upstairs, which became smokelogged, had to be rescued by firefighters and were lifted down a ladder. They were taken to the Countess of Chester Hospital but were allowed home after four hours. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943853

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Son's anger at dad's wait for ambulance
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN ELDERLY man was forced to wait 40 minutes in agonising pain because there were no ambulances in Wrexham to get to him sooner, his son has claimed. Francis Parry, 73, of Falcon Road in Wrexham, fell in the kitchen breaking his thigh bone. He spent 12 hours on the kitchen floor before dragging himself to the phone. When his son Mark, 36, arrived the next day he saw his father needed emergency help. He rang the ambulance at 1.22pm and 20 minutes later there was no sign of it arriving. The ambulance arrived 40 minutes later and an angry Mark asked why there had been such a long wait and claims to have been told that there were no ambulances in Wrexham and that the ambulance had come from Corwen. Mr Parry\'s son said: "I find it disgusting that there weren\'t any ambulances in Wrexham county. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943027

properties.name: 12/06/07 - BBC presenter joins Blue Planet campaign
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA BBC presenter has joined forces with an aquarium to raise awareness of the world\'s oceans. Fresh from presenting BBC 2 programme Coast, ocean enthusiast Miranda Krestovnikoff attended an Ocean Awareness gala dinner at the Blue Planet Aquarium to highlight the importance of looking after the world\'s seas and supporting the Marine Reserves Now campaign. The campaign, designed to encourage the Government to create a network of Marine Reserves around the UK coast where marine life is protected from exploitation was discussed as part of Ocean awareness weekend which ran between June 9 and 10. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943980

properties.name: 12/06/07 - Car clamper attacked with clamp
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN ANGRY driver struck a vehicle clamper after learning his car had been targeted in Chester. The man returned to Crook Street, Newtown, to find his car had been clamped. Two men were working as vehicle clampers on the street and the offender struck one of them with part of a clamp, leaving him with a broken left arm. Cheshire Constabulary spokesman Glyn Hellam said: "The disgruntled vehicle owner is described as mixed race, 5ft 7in tall and in his late 20s. "He was wearing a black T-shirt with a striped motif on the front. "He was accompanied by another man who is described as white, tall and slim with short dark hair who had no part in the incident on Monday, June 4. "They both made off in a white van." Police are appealing for anyone with information to contact DC Mike Beamish at Chester Specialist Investigation Unit on 0845 458 0000 or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2946010

properties.name: 12/06/07 - TB tests at school in disease scare
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline  A TUBERCULOSIS scare at a local school has resulted in screening tests being offered to staff and children. More than 200 pupils and staff members at Holywell High School who have been in close contact with a certain member of staff diagnosed with TB, have been offered the tests. A meeting will be held after school on Thursday, when concerned parents can ask questions to a panel of health experts. However, the National Public Health Service of Wales (NPHS) has stressed the likelihood of TB spreading to the children is "very low". The member of staff, who has been off work since May 24, was admitted to Glan Clwyd Hospital but has now been discharged and is recovering well. Testing of the adult\'s close household contacts has shown there has been no spread of the infection to them. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2945694

properties.name: 12/06/07 - Villagers flock to save surgery
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline HUNDREDS of residents are backing a campaign to keep a Bagillt surgery open. Doctors J. C. Kapoor and locum T. R. Lakshmish, whose main surgery is Allt Goch Medical Centre in Flint, have applied to the Flintshire Local Health Board (FLHB) to close Wern Surgery in Bagillt. A petition against the closure organised by Shirley Edwards has now attracted 402 signatures and is due to be handed to Cllr Kevin Jones later this week. Wern Surgery currently operates three days a week and has 405 patients on its books. In the application presented to the FLHB, Dr Kapoor set out several reasons for closing the surgery. He said for the period of August to December, 2006 compared to the same period in 2005, there was a drop of 111 in the number of patients attending sessions. There is also the problem of lone working with the receptionist having to open the surgery by herself to book patients in for the doctor and staying to clear things away and lock up after the doctor had left. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2945160

properties.name: 13/06/07 - 'Business as usual' after TB alert
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePARENTS at Holywell High School are being reassured it is business as usual after a TB scare. Screening tests are being offered to 210 staff and children who have been in close contact with a member of staff at the school who has been diagnosed with TB. However, the National Public Health Service say the risk of the disease spreading is very low and there have been no reported cases of any children coming down with TB. And Flintshire Council\'s education department has confirmed that the school is operating as normal. A spokesman said: "Acting on the advice of the National Public Health Service for Wales, letters and information sheets are being sent to the parents of children who will need to be screened. "The school and the LEA will continue to liaise closely with the National Public Health Service for Wales team dealing with this matter. "The school will continue to operate normally." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2946498

properties.name: 13/06/07 - Churchyard yobs smash up ancient tomb
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineVANDALS seriously damaged a 19th century grave in a churchyard wrecking spree in a bid to find a body, a canon fears. Yobs targeted St Giles Parish Church in Wrexham in an attack which has left rector canon Geoffrey Marshall and volunteers \'disgusted\' as they count the cost of repairs. The vandalism to the grave, which dates back to 1803, is the latest in a series of incidents of anti-social behaviour in the area surrounding the church. Volunteer John Griffiths said: "You can\'t get inside their mind can you? It is really terrible. I am absolutely disgusted, especially when you think of all the men working here every day to keep the place tidy." The Leader was shown a number of areas in the church grounds which have been blighted with graffiti, litter and criminal damage. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2948754

properties.name: 13/06/07 - Flintshire beauty spot touted on the internet as a sex site
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSTRANGERS meeting for sex in a beauty spot are making life a nightmare for local families. Internet chatrooms are directing hoards of people looking for casual sex with strangers to Penymynydd woods. For years, residents and councillors have been concerned that the quiet woodland off the A5104 is being used as a meeting place for men searching for sex in public. But the numbers parking up in the lay-bys around the woods are growing due to the use of online \'cottaging\', \'dogging\' and \'cruising\' forums recommending the Flintshire site to hundreds of people across the UK and even abroad. As a result, dog walkers, residents and even children have witnessed men and couples performing sex acts in the woods, which are part of the Gladstone Estate and the bordering St John the Baptist Primary School. Police say they are aware of the activities and are constantly patrolling the area. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2948392

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Dad died days after roof fall
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN has died days after falling from a skylight while working as a roofing contractor. Paul Alker, of Brynteg, known as Little Will, was working as a contractor at the Comet store in Wrexham on Thursday when he fell and was admitted to hospital with a broken collar bone. He was allowed home for the weekend to see his family but was re-admitted for surgery on Monday. The operation to put pins in his collar bone was successful and he was laughing and joking in the ward the same evening. But the following morning his partner received a call saying that Mr Alker had collapsed and died. The family are waiting for post mortem results to reveal the cause of death. Paul, who was born in Liverpool, lived in Brynteg from the age of three. He attended Brynteg Primary School and then Groves High School. He started work as a construction worker as he loved to be outside. He was only three days in to his new job as a roofing contractor when the accident occurred. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2953835

properties.name: 14/06/07 - End of an era as city's Odeon cinema closes
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline CHESTER\'S last remaining city centre cinema will close for good tonight - June 14. A year-long campaign – led by city MP Christine Russell and backed by thousands of people from in and around Chester – to keep the much-loved Odeon up-and-running has failed. The management of Odeon UCL Cinemas Ltd has given up its tenancy of the Grade II listed "iconic" art deco building in Hunter Street, and the building\'s owners, South Yorkshire-based nightclub specialist The Brook Group, will now attempt to persuade the city council to favour its plans for the cinema complex which celebrated its 70th birthday last October. The 25 Odeon staff have promised The Brook Group they will vacate the building by June 30. An Odeon spokesman said: "We would like to thank all guests who have visited the cinema over the years. We would also like to thank the Odeon team members who have contributed so much to the running of the cinema." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2954356

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Massive hunt for boys, 7, after school dare
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A PLAYGROUND dare spiralled into a huge three-hour search across Deeside for two missing schoolboys. Thankfully, the boys were found safe and well and the mother of one of them has expressed her thanks to the police officers, dog handlers, the helicopter team and members of the public who searched frantically for the children. At around 1pm on Tuesday, Maria Cooke, of South Green, Sealand, was at work when she received the phone call every parent dreads. A teacher from Sealand Community Primary School informed her that her son Stephen Edwards, seven, had been missing for the last 20 minutes and was nowhere to be found on school property. The school had notified the police and two officers came to collect Maria from work. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2954023

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Midnight dip man warned of river perils
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN who went for a midnight dip in the River Dee "because he was cold" has been warned he could have put his life in danger. The man, thought to be in his mid to late 30s, was spotted by a concerned member of the public wading around the weir near the Old Dee Bridge in Handbridge He was wearing shorts and had left his other clothes at the Bandstand near the Groves. When Chester Fire Station crew arrived, the man was swimming near the bank of the Salmon Leap flats in Handbridge. Blue Watch firefighter Andy Doyle said: "I was on the rescue boat and the man was wading across the weir in the river, and then swimming near the bank of the Salmon Leap flats. "He seemed a bit confused and we said to him that he should come out but he said he didn\'t see there was any danger. "This isn\'t true. Even though it is the summer, there were several dangers lurking. "The current is unpredictable, and debris could come up, the temperature is pretty cold, and despite it being summer if anyone is in deep water for too long they could catch hypothermia." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2953817

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Mum's alarm at missing hand scrub in hospital
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A MOTHER who took her son to Accident and Emergency at Wrexham\'s Maelor Hospital has spoken of her alarm at seeing empty soap dispensers in the waiting room. The mother, who does not want to be identified, took her son to the hospital after he broke his arm. She said: "Apart from the lengthy wait, what concerned me and other patients was the lack of disinfectant hand scrub in the waiting area. There were bottles attached to the wall but these were empty. "Myself and others did ask at the reception desk and told them the bottles were empty but the receptionist told us all that she had told the nurses at least four times and they had not filled them up." The same day the lady visited a friend in the hospital who told her the patient opposite had been isolated as she had contracted MRSA. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2950193

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Village's annual scarecrow trail keeps drivers on their toes
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA scarecrow dressed as a policeman has had drivers hitting the brakes in one Cheshire village. A scarecrow dressed as a policeman has had drivers hitting the brakes in one Cheshire village. The masterpiece was created by Christopher Strong, of Warrington Road, Mickle Trafford, who made the scarecrow as part of a Scarecrow Trail in the area, which began on Monday. Traffic began to slow and put on their brakes along the 40mph stretch of road after mistaking the scarecrow for a policeman and so Mr Strong, 58, felt obliged to move the it into his driveway. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2952933

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Villagers defiant after yobs attack scarecrows
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline

properties.name: 14/06/07 - £1.3m revamp underway to transform city's station road
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWORK has begun on the £1.3 million scheme to transform the road and footways outside Chester Railway Station. A 150-year-old Birkenhead Railway company manhole cover was lifted to mark the event which will be stored until it is moved to a new location once the project is completed. During the six month scheme York stone will replace the existing flagstones outside the station and the roundabout is to be moved near the station\'s west pay and display car park. The station square is to be remodelled with the taxi rank moved from the east wing to the west, linked to City Rail Link buses. There will also be a drop off point and short stay car parking. Six new bus stops with shelters will be placed either side of City Road as well as in the square itself and parts of the road are to be reconstructed and resurfaced. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2954898

properties.name: 15/06/07 - Man arrested over roofer's death
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN has been arrested on suspicion of manslaughter by gross negligence after a father of one died days after falling from a skylight at a Wrexham store. Paul Alker, 33, was working as a roofing contractor at the Comet store on Mount Street when he fell last Thursday. Mr Alker, of Holborn Crescent, Brynteg, was admitted to hospital with a broken collar bone, and discharged over the weekend. He underwent surgery on his injury on Monday and appeared to be well that evening, but the following morning his partner received a call to say he had collapsed and died. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2957417
